reviewText:
Short version: 82%Dreamscapes 2 tries to venture into the hidden object game territory, but at its core it is still a casual point ‘n’ click. The story is a direct sequel, but with shorter dreams of somewhat wavering quality.

Long version:Shaman Games likes to create games that look and feel like hidden object games, but are actually lightweight point ‘n’ clicks. Dreamscapes 2: Nightmare’s Heir is a rare exception: it retains most of the developer’s usual clever puzzle design, but this time there is a larger focus on item gathering, and there are even a few traditional hidden objects scenes.

The story brings us back to Laura (the damsel in distress of the first game), who, despite her new-found superpowers, is only present as a supporting character; it is up to the new protagonist to save her husband. His dreams are probably more mundane than Laura’s were, but there are many of them, so even the duller ones quickly give way to the better segments.
Still, it becomes obvious fairly early that despite their number, the new dreams don’t last long. This naturally results in a very short game (about half of an afternoon long), even by casual game standards.

reviewText:
After saving Laura from her dreams and from the Sandman, she has now the Power. However, she can't use it for herself and the Sandman used that knowledge to attack her dear friend and now husband Tim. You're the only one she can count on, so, you're going to save Tim from his nightmares and put an end to the Sandman's revenge.

Dreamscapes: Nightmare's Heir is the sequel of Dreamscapes: The Sandman. While it's not an obligation to play the first game, I suggest you to strongly do it, as you will have a better understand of what's happening. The story is still nicely written and if you played the first game, you knew that there was going to be a sequel at one point. Here it is, with the Sandman ready to take over Tim and taunting you about failing this time (though he was sure of that in the first game too). As usual, a cute creature is helping you, though it's not Benny anymore but another one.

There was a huge change in the gameplay: now, you have hidden objects scenes included, where the first game was just a point-&-click with puzzles. It doesn't change anything in the end, as it's still pleasant to play puzzles (they're easy) and to clear the scenes, with a well-balances difficulty. The beholders are still there, however, where in the first game, it was easier to find them, here, they're kinda very small apart for some.

As you're now in Tim's nightmare, you have different fears to face than in Laura's story. They're less into exotic" locations: everything is way more darker than for Laura - if I think about the depths of the sea and the swamp - else

reviewText:
Very easy, quick casual adventure and Hidden Object game.

This game focuses more on collecting objects to reach new areas and has very few Hidden Object scenes and puzzles. The HO scenes require little effort as there are few items in scene besides the one your looking for. The story element is also easy as you have a limited inventory and so only few logical choices. Only a few logic puzzles which aren't taxing. The graphics and sound are okay. The story is again okay. The best part for me was finding the cute beholders in the areas, though that was also easy. There is an achievement menu inside the game, most of which you will pick up as you go along without trying.

I played in windowed mode and encountered no bugs. I had no issue with clicking on items.
Overall I would give this an okay. Good for crayon eaters.
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
A significant improvement over Dreamscapes: The Sandman.

There are a few easy hidden-object scenes, but this is primarily a casual point-and-click adventure. It's interesting and long enough that it's worth playing, but you are advised to keep your expectations low.

As with Dreamscapes 1, the English edition has awful voice acting and script. Also, though it has achievements, they are not linked to Steam. One of the achievements was bugged for me -- I completed it, but it did not register.

reviewText:
Summary:
Competent, bug-free adventure game (find object X to use at location Y) with some hidden objects and puzzles thrown in. But lacks greatness. (Completed in just over 4hrs, minus a few in-game achievements)
7/10

Pros:
+ Nice animations and graphics
+ Some fantastical settings/scenarios


Cons:
- Lip-synch is bad. Really bad.
- Music, plot, voice acting is not memorable. Just ... OK.

reviewText: If you've played the first then you'll kinda like this game. Has the same layout as the first game only the story isn't as good. This time you're in Tims dreams trying to save him and defeat the sandman. Down part is the dtory isnt as rich, the ending is totally rubbish and tyhe bonus play ending is a cop out. Wondering if there'st to be a third game. The game isnt as long as the previous and I'd recommend you play that one if you haven't done so. The art is good and the creepy feel is there, it has a twist on gameplay which makes it more fun than your bog standard HOG.

reviewText: This game has two very terrible attributes. First off there is no skip button for puzzles. In the original game there was but the converted Steam version left it out. I am stuck on a puzzle with no way to get past it. Secondly the mouse cursor does not line up with what your trying to click. It's way off in some cases.\n\nThis game is a no go unless they fix the above mentioned problems.

reviewText: This second chapter of the Dreamscapes series is one of the best HOGs on Steam even if is very short for experienced players, so maybe it's better buying it on sale. Detailed graphics, good HO scenes, fluid gameplay. Only a few puzzles but there's also an extra chapter after the main game and in-game achievements. Having played the 1st chapter is not absolutely necessary but it'll help you understand the characters a little better. At expert difficulty you have no hints but you can switch the settings while in-game if you need help. Recommended!

I like hogs but finishing this one was mostly a chore. Too often you have no idea where to go and there is no map to tell you where there are actions waiting for you. The beholders are a nice touch but two or three were just impossible to find, maybe a bug? The puzzles are mostly ok but sometimes you have to put something exactly in the right place in order to make something work. Also the area's where you click are way too big.

I wanted to be generous.  I know that the HOG industry relies on shovelware and hasty localizations.  I tried to be forgiving. But just too many things are wrong with Dreamscapes: Nightmare's Heir.

First, the game is very short.  I completed the whole thing, including the Bonus Chapter, in under two hours.

The voice acting is subpar, and some of the translations are rather shaky.  The typical supernatural antagonist is particularly sketchy -- his goals and motivations (other than general maliciousness) change every time he monologues.

The ending, and the second ending, after the Bonus Chapter, are both abrupt and unsatisfying.

The HO scenes and puzzles are all very easy, with one possible exception, if you've never encountered the Eight Queens problem before.  At least one HO scene in the Bonus Chapter, however, commits the cardinal sin of including multiple objects that satisfy the target description, and demanding that you find the right one.

The video sequences, in fairness, were up to the standard for the genre, and the music was mostly good, with the exception of one ear-grating synth chorus effect.

A few flaws are always forgiveable in this genre, but here, there are just too many.  I cannot recommend.

This game is good for beginners of HOGs (Hidden Object Games). The find the items mini-games are a little easier on the eyes, ala fewer drawing/picture on background that blends in instead of an item. The puzzle games are a little lacking for the hardcore as in so much hand holding to point out. The animation is funny on how Tim gets into a deadly predicament that is cliche for some. Other than that... It is an average game, but I would recommend to a friend.\n\nNote: The play time is off due to me watching a friend's podcast at the time playing. But, this is a short game, about 2 1/2 hours with the bonus episode. Or 3 hours of finding all the watchers/diary. Only missed 5 watchers and 1 page of the diary in my playthrough.

Definitely worse than the first game, but you can play it if you're bored. It's an average HOG really, not particularly impressive but not horrible either. Still, it gets the dishonourable award for the worst hint system ever.
